intro: Magnolia acuminata subsp. cordata, commonly known as the narrow-leaf magnolia, is a deciduous tree native to eastern North America. It is characterized by its elongated, lance-shaped leaves that are typically 5–10 cm long. The plant produces showy, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in early spring before the leaves emerge. Its bark is smooth and gray, becoming fissured with age. This subspecies is often found in moist, well-drained soils in forested areas.
